reviewText: This one actually managed to scare me. Not the jumpscares or cheap noises, but the atmosphere. It has a feeling of reliving your childhood nightmares: monsters coming to get you in your bedroom. Only two nights in, and it terrifies me already. For the other three games, I only really cared about them for the story that was supposedly hidden behind it, waiting to be uncovered. This one, however, I actually feel scared by. Of all of the series, I recommend this one much more than the others. VERY MUCH RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Apparently Halloween is on the 23rd of July accroding to Scott Cawthon...

--------------------

Edit:
Ok, since this has somehow become one of the top reviews for this game, I decided to edit it so it's actually helpful. Firstly, the game was teased with images showing the Halloween date. This has led many fans to believe that the release date for this game was going to be on Halloween. However, Scott later announced that Five Nights at Freddy's 4 was going to be released sometime in August and that a DLC would be released on Halloween. But, even Scott himself said that he is bad with release dates and he released it early, on the 23rd of July. Ok, Now I'm actually going to review the game:

Summary (TL;DR): It's completely different to the previous FNAF games but it's more scary and it looks better.

Actual Review:
This is the 4th and probably the final game in the Five Night's at Freddy's series, with an expansion pack coming out on Halloween and a movie being worked on which is planned to be released sometime in 2017.
The game itself differs quite significantly from the previous 3 games because instead of playing as an adult security guard during a night shift, you play as a young child at home. This means that there are no cameras, no high-tech lockable doors and no power management. Before each night, the player is presented in an 8-bit styled minigame which explains the backstory and shows how the child is locked in his room and later starts walking around the house.
Then the night starts, the gameplay mainly consists of running around the room, using a flashlight, and holding the doors closed as you can't actually lock them. You can run to the left door which is where Bonnie is, the right door where Chica is, the central closet where Foxy is, and you can look behind you where miniature Freddies or Fredbears can be. When you approach the door, you must actually listen  for someone breathing which forces you to turn the volume up which later makes the unexpected jumpscares louder and scarier. If there is no breathing, you can flash the flashlight to check if anyone is there. If there is breathing, then you must hold the door shut and wait to avoid being killed. You must also look behind you to make sure that too many mini-Freddies don't gang up on you. Then there's Foxy in the closet and I have no idea how he works.
So that is the basic gameplay for the actual nights, however, there is one more thing which starts happening in between nights after night 1, the Plushtrap minigame. In the minigame, Plushtrap (a miniature version of Springtrap from FNAF 3) sits on a tall chair in front of you. He will not move if you shine your flashlight at him and he might move if you don't. There is an x" marked on the floor in front of Plushtrap and the objective is to get Plushtrap to stand on that "x". To do this
date: you must not shine your flashlight for a few seconds to get him to move. If you manage to make him stand on the "x" within the time limit
recommended: then the next night will be 2 hours shorter.\n\nTo conclude
hoursPlayed: this seems to be the best and the scariest Five Nights at Freddy's game out of all of them. The animations are much more detailed and smooth and the gameplay is much more interesting than the previous games."

reviewText: FIVE NIGHTS AT FREDDY'S 4 REVIEW\n\nFirst off, it has taken me forever to beat this game. Not because it was impossible, but because I've been incredibly busy. I honestly have to say that I really like this game. The obvious camera-checking mechanic is gone, and in turn has yet again changed the game entirely. That's the thing about the FNAF games. No one game is the same. They aren't cheap remakes, they're each innovative and change how the game is played in their own way. The FNAF series in my opinion really picked up around the third installment. In that game, there was less randomly-generated stuff and more skill-required gameplay. THAT is what the game needed. In the first two games, there was frankly too much random-generated BS that would kill you when it's not even your fault. In FNAF4, you have to rely entirely on learning sound cues and knowing where to go at the right time. You have to adapt to a new kind of game. You aren't overwhelmed with keeping up with things, you just have to listen and act adequately. This is a hard game. I mean that when I say it, I died many times on the first night. Granted that's because I still had to learn how it works, but it's no joke. All the way up until the game mixes things up on Night 5. You defend yourself against one animatronic, as opposed to four (hearkening back to FNAF3). You get so used to hearing certain audio cues, then realizing that Hey
recommended: . You check outside your door and see something you've never seen before, and immediately die. Night 5 changes, even while you play. You're constantly learning new things and adapting to them. Not to even get started on Night 6 (which I beat) and Nightmare (which I did not). Scott receives a lot of hate for putting out the games too fast, but that's just how he is. He works exceptionally hard, and he outdoes himself. He makes good games. Overall, it's a good game. The story to be uncovered is intriguing, and the gameplay has nearly been perfected. It's a horror game, but one you can have fun and enjoy yourself with. I recommend giving it a try.
hoursPlayed: August 10, 2015

reviewText:
As the supposed final chapter to the Five Nights at Freddy's Series, comes a much scarier (my personal opinion) experience than the original games. That being said, this game does suffer a lot of flaws regardless of the scary atmosphere and animatronics. One major feature of the series has disappeared; the cameras. Even though this can be seen as a bad decision; the game behaves much differently than the past chapters in the series, and it makes sense why the cameras are gone once you boot up the game for the first time. Feature-wise, I think this game takes the cake for having the best features in the entire game series; and its so different that at first it really doesn't feel like a Five Nights at Freddy's game until you get jumpscared. Although the formula is getting worn out; I do believe that this has the best animations and jumpscares in the series.

Story:

The Five Nights at Freddy's games always had great stories, and I can say the same about this game. Although the ending to the third game was perfect, and the fourth games ending is just a little below the third game's ending, it still has a deep ending. Without going too much into spoilers, this story will confuse you, and make you stop and think about how this connects to the others more than FNAF 3 did.

Verdict:

This spectacular ending to the game's series is almost as good as it should be, throwing jumpscares at you everytime you fail, and has new features makes it mostly different than the other ones and has a satisfying story; making this game one of the best in the series. Although there are many flaws; the game makes up for it with its deep story, and if do not like deep stories; than this game is pretty much not for you. Maybe even the series isn't for you. But that being said, this game is a pretty good horror game; and even though its not like other top AAA games with being able to move around; the sense of not being able to move creates more fear and suspense. But, after a while the jumpscares start to get old, removing some of the fear you got the first time you were jumpscared.

Rating:

8/10

+ Great Story
+ Scarier than most of the other games in the series
+ Awesome Jumpscares
+ Newer Features

- Game's fear factor gets old a little after getting all jumpscares.
- Formula is still a little worn out.
- Didn't live all the way up to the FNAF 3 ending.

If you do not like Five Nights at Freddy's, do not buy this game (obviously).

Although the game has DLC coming out soon, which may not even be DLC, it can still totally make up for the ending. But I reviewed this game's core, and since the DLC may not be content added to the game, the game still has a weaker story than FNAF 3.

EDIT: In my personal opinion the story is deep and brilliant, but regardless its still great story :)

reviewText:
If you found the previous games in the series to be underwhelming, I recommend you give this one a go. Almost everything people had problems with previously have been addressed to create an ideal, more traditional horror game that still feels unique and stays true to the concept of Five Nights at Freddy's.

Contrary to popular belief, this is not just a jumpscare simulator. The game creates a perfect atmosphere with the use of ambient noises (Dogs barking off in the distance, crickets chirping, chimes of a grandfather clock, the footsteps of the monsters lurking through your home, etc.) and settings. That, combined with the tension, anticipation, and fear of the unknown that the mechanics create (similar to the first game), you'll find yourself terrified long before you experience a jumpscare.

That's not to say the jumpscares are ineffective. In fact, they will give you heart attacks. A clever new mechanic requires you to listen carefully for breathing outside your door before you choose to shine the flashlight or hold the door shut. If you hear the breathing of a monster, you have to close the door until you hear the footsteps of it walking away. If you choose instead to shine the light in its face (which normally makes them go away if they're at the far end of the hall), you get jumped. This makes you turn your volume up to listen for the audio cues, resulting in heart-pounding scares.

This time around, the jumpscares can happen in multiple situations, and aren't only reserved for when you fail the night. There isn't a single jumpscare that's predictable (the only exception might be before you flash the light down the hall). It doesn't play by the same rules as the others where you're always safe from a scare until you prompt an opportunity for it to happen, they just happen whenever. Think you're safe until you check the doors? Nope, Foxy will scream at you out of nowhere when you go to check the closet. Or Bonnie will lunge at you when you turn around from checking the bed, in your own room. There's also a cryptic backstory told through 8-bit minigames between nights, which also has its fair share of scares (albeit not nearly as scary as the main nights, as they're not supposed to be).

If you're a fan of horror games, you should play Five Nights at Freddy's 4. Scott Cawthon has really outdone himself with this game, he's listened to previous criticism and improved the horror aspect of the game significantly. It's a great way to end the series, and we can expect a free content update on Halloween that will make your eight dollars more than worth it if you didn't feel so already.

reviewText: Interesting spin on what we know of the series. No cameras, no phone guy, and from what I can tell, no batteries or system errors in the game. However, that being said, the game has some loading problems for me; I run over to one of the doors, and it takes a few seconds for the doorway to load, and it takes even longer for me to be able to use my flashlight. As we all know, in FNAF games, timing and precision is key, so this isn't helping me survive. Also, there are the fullscreen problems, which ruin the immersion a bit. ALSO, as 1,987 people have already said, the 'breathing' is much too quiet, and I can barely hear it at full volume. To be fair, I don't have working headphones, so the audio might be a bit better if I had them. I personally can't get past night 2, and have been killed by Bonnie, Chica, and the cupcake numerous times. (I like to call the cupcake 'Chucky.') We'll see if that works out. Overall, it's looking pretty good, but we could have waited until August 8th so Scott could clean up the bugs.\nEDIT: So after the update, Scott fixed the fullscreen problems, and he made the breathing louder. Now the only problem is the lag it gives me when first running to a door, but that might just be because my computer isn't exactly meant for gaming. I'm still horrible at the game, and I still can't get past night 2, but now I can't blame the game or Scott for my awfulness. Awesome!

reviewText:
The transistion from visuals to audio is what makes this great. For three games, I had nothing but cameras to keep myself safe and learnt when to look and when to focus on what was near my office. Now, all I have is my skill and my headphones to guide me to 6AM. I love that. During the last three games, there was a point where you would eventually get jumpscared so many times that they would become numb and somewhat frustrating. That is not a problem here.

Here, you are always on your toes. You must think, you must listen and making the slightest mistake will kill you. Here in FNAF4, it is not about chance and luck like the last three games. It is up to you as the player to make the right decision; do you open the door or flash down the hallway and pray that Fredbear and friends are not lurking in the shadows? You need to be damn good to survive this nightmare.

Rating: 9/10.
Series As a Whole: 1 > 4 > 2 >3.
If you enjoyed the last three games, get this. If you are someone who does not enjoy the franchise, you will most likely NOT enjoy this but that's fine, everyone is entitled to their own opinion. Those who do purchase it, all I can say is: good luck and have fun." :)"

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4 is the final chapter in the Five Nights at Freddy's series, together with being the last game, it's also the scariest game in the series as well.
The game is COMPLETELY different in the gameplay than all of the previous games, you don't have a security camera anymore, all you have to defend yourself is a flashlight, to scare the animatronics away.
The gameplay is made in such a way, that you need to focus on the audio cues, making you to concentrate on the game carefully, making you feel like you're a part of it all.
The animations in this game are amazing, everything is now completely fluid, and doesn't feel like they're laggy" at all.
The graphics and everything are amazing too

reviewText:
Ugh. Where do I begin... Sit down and I'll start from the beginning.

Five nights at freddy's, since Game 2, has been growing stale. The game is getting boring to the point that I'm qualifying it as a Red light-green light simulator, the lore is getting lame (And no, Game theory does NOT count as your lore source), and it's the same shmuck each, and every time.

As a casual fan of the first, this installment, almost does nothing better to the series as a whole. If there is one thing I can say he nailed, was the child-nightmare atmoshephere. The rest? Well, let me spell it out for you.

SOUND The sound is varied at many times. Your goal is to listen for breathing noises behind 3 doors. If you hear it, you close the door. Simple mechanic. Now here lies the problem...The breathing? Doesn't exist. It just doesn't. I have fine hearing, I have a optimized computer, and I have headphones for maximum sounds. Still nothing. This is the thing that pains me most. Your main mechanic doesn't work.

GRAPHICS The overall atmosphere of the game is, to me, spot on. It's definitely better than the last two games in the series. The second was too similar to the first, and the third was just ugly to look at. Here? It's got the best of both. You're a child, locked in his room, in the middle of the night, when those that go bump in said night, are awake, and ready to take you into a brand new no-banana underworld. There is, one problem with it: Just like the other games, it gets repetitive, real fast. You're stuck in a single room, the entire time. No walking around, no trying to run, no, you sit there, and you keep your mouth shut. There''s nothing else, but jumpscares, and if you know Ol' me, than you would know that Jumpscares
date: are Diet Scares". Subtlety is best if you wanna get a genuine scare. Wanna know a good game with the perfect fear factor? Majora's Mask. I hear you Little Ankle biters sayin' "That game's OLD! Get with the times!" Well

reviewText:
To describe why i like is hard. It's a simple, yet extremely complex game that makes you use you senses to get through it. In that sense, it's original, but the the rest of the gameplay is rather the same, but diffrent.
Lemme elaborate on that. The lack of camras, locks, any mask, or anything like that gives the game a challange right away. It alienates those who have gotten used to FNaF being like that. That's not a bad thing, but it isn't the gratest thing in the world.
The first of the few new mechanics is the door set. The three doors that your worried about are the two bedroom doors and the closet door. You must check all three of them. Often. The bedroom doors have their own mechanic i'll go over later, but the closet door: you run up to it, flash you light, and if somebody's there, spam every key and pray to god that you don't die. Easy peasy.
The next new mechanic is the two bedroom doors. These have the mechanic of quiet sounds. This means you have to use earphones with the volume all the way up to hear the (lack of) noises. If you hear breathing, close the door, if not, then shine your light.
The third mechanic is the bed. The bed is behind you, meaning you have to turn around every now and again to check for freddles. I'll leave you to google freddles.
Given that this is a long reveiw, i'll end it here, but that's the basics of the game.
Peace

reviewText: I have to say, this game is truly the best one in the series. It abandoned the camera system which is good since you've  always ignored most of the cams in the late game anyway. I'm very satisfied with the way it is now. This time it really has you in constant fear. You can't immediately check for lurking threats. You have to wait and listen for ominous thunder-like breaths or else you fall victim to your own impatience. My favorite new thing is that it has some sort of final boss, an extra menacing monstrosity, which will undoubtedly haunt your dreams. It's not too hard either  unlike the 3rd game  and is quite managable. Although it has weird performance issues when loading the screens at the start of any night, it doesn't affect the gameplay enough to make you upset. I heavily recommend this game to anyone who's even slightly interested.\n10/10

reviewText: Up until recently, I've been happy with the FNAF storyline. The lore was deep, the clues were clever, and all in all it was an enjoyable romp... but, I can't help but feel like this game ends in the worst way possible. I don't find a lot of pleasure in progressing through a mystery, wracking my brain to put the loose pieces together, staying up for hours trying not to die of a heartattack in my chair, only to be met with a brick wall at the end of things. It's like telling a disjointed story for 4 chapters and the final pages are all blank. Sort of like The hero stood before the keep with his sword drawn. reviewText:
OMG GUYS HE FIXED IT AND IT'S SUPER SCARY AND SUPER AWESOME LOVE IT TO DEATH!!!

I initially gave this game a negative review because I could NOT hear any sound que's letting me know if I should shut the door or not, I even went as far as recording it, ramping up the volume, and double checking to STILL hear nothing. But after a quick update by the AMAZING Scott Cawthon, it ALL makes sense now!!!

First, he turned up the volume so you could hear the effects so you know if you should shut the door or not. Second, DON'T decide quickly, this is a MUCH slower paced game then the other FNAF's. You should wait about 5 seconds at each door BEFORE deciding whether or not to shut it. DO NOT RUSH, THAT is the problem most people, including myself, have had about this game.

Now that I FINALLY understand it, I LOVE THIS GAME TO DEATH!!! And I hate it, but I LOVE hating it cause it's SOOO fun and SOOO scary! 10/10 Best FNAF ever, and SCARIEST FnaF ever.

Scott, we were all confused, so ignore the negative reviews. We didn't understand how to play and what to do. But now that you explained it, IT IS PHENOMENAL!! You have really out-done yourself this time, my friend. It's obvious to see you really care about this game, and it's community, and it shows, and we all love you for it. Seriously PHENOMENAL job!!!

reviewText:
I'm beginning to think that the numbers at the end of the titles are actually how long the dev expects you to last for without destroying your escape key.

The latest member of the FNAF family brings with it a completely new setting and some nifty, if not particularly well executed, mechanics. It's apparent that FNAF4 is designed to be played in a pitch black room with the sound all the way up and no outside distractions, but I was wishing for the brown pants after a well timed jump scare in a brightly lit room!

FNAF4 is a nice game to pick up for 5 minutes here or there when you're in need of a quick adrenaline boost.

Good for:
- Fans of the other FNAF games
- People who enjoy terrorising other people/small children
- People who like those car adverts with a screaming zombie at the end

Bad for:
- The frail elderly
- People with pacemakers
- People with toy-related paranoia
- Your keyborad

reviewText:
What else is there to say but it's just another fnaf game... Look left, look right, turn around, look in closet, do boring minigame with a springtrap plushie. Massive frame drops and near crashes, 10/10 best game 2015-2032 = IGN (Although it's still better than FNAF 3... Well anything is better than FNAF 3)

I will say that the atmosphere is good, you're a child trapped in your room, that feels better than just sitting in your office. One issue with the gameplay that I keep hearing and I agree with is that the breathing mechanic is a little... wonky. Half the time the breathing will be overshadowed by the sounds of the animatronics running around the house or the crickets chirping outside.

The ending and the 5th night of the game is a little poor, the ending is so abrupt to give reason for why FNAF 4 must and could" exist.

If you like the simplistic playstyle of another FNAF game

reviewText: A return to form for the series. After FNAF 3 I was ready for the series to come to a close. reviewText: Five Nights at Freddys 4 is probably the scariest game out of all the four games in the series. Five Nights at Freddys 4 takes place inside a house then in a establishment. This is my favorite game out of the four because it builds up more suspense for the player. Also this game has no cameras or monitors, instead you only have a flashlight to keep you protected. It also has lots of modes that allow you to change the settings of the night, for example you can make the characters harder by setting their difficulty by 1-20, or you can see when they are coming. In my opinion, this is a very nice game. I think it is worth playing and trying out.

reviewText:
I am going to give you cold, hard facts of this game. No overly-obssessed fanboy or full-on hater talk.

If you like challenging gameplay, get this game.
If you like scaring yourself, get this game.
If you like the the thought of death is coming, but do not know when it will come, get this game.

This game, along with the others in the series, are done well. Very few glitches, except for the lag at the start. Plushtrap is the part that gets my heart racing. I know how Markiplier feels. Death is coming, but you don't know when. When you think you are safe, BAM! They get ya good. I just wanna lie on the ground, moaning. Many people do not like inanimate objects that come to life, and these games use that effect to the max. I highly recommend this game if you just need a quick and challenging horror game to take $8 and 10 hours of your time. or more if you like it that much.

reviewText:
These are my thoughts on all of the FNAF games:
FNAF: Very new and hyped. Game was fairly simple and creepy. Loved seeing characters looking at you through the window while you slowly run out of power. Best game in series by far.
FNAF 2: Too much stuff. Hated winding up the music box and managing all of the animatronics. My least favorite to be sure.
FNAF 3: Series kind of ran dry. 1 animatronic who really didn't have a good jumpscare. System reboots are stupid.
FNAF 4: Relies on hearing to get cheap scares since you listen so hard. Animatronics are trying too hard to be scary. Overall: eh.
The whole series: I'd rather watch it than play it. I would wait for these games to go suuuuper cheap before you buy them because they are worth AT MOST $1.

reviewText:
This is the kind of game that really needs a neutral rating. If you like the other games give this one a thumbs up, if you're indifferent to the series, give it a thumbs down.

FNAF4 is the first game to not take place in some kind of security control room though it does function entirely the same in terms of gameplay. You're checking a left and right doorway which now replace the left and right hallway doors from the other games and your flashlight is the primary mode of defense.

FNAF 4 relies a lot more heavily on audio cues, listening to footsteps, laugher, etc though this is ruined by those obnoxious jump scares that will pop your eardrums with repeated play. Again however the art style looks great, it does sound incredible even though it still runs in a horrid resolution.

Overall, the series has had its run through Youtubers and a younger demographic which is fine, but maybe it's time for Freddy to retire.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmlerdZ0hL0
voteText: 49 of 93 people (53%) found this review helpful 8 people found this review funny

reviewText:
There's a lot of hate for this franchise for some reason. Nobody's been forced to buy the game. Nobody's been forced to sit through playthroughs. It's a popular game and it's easy to see why, through its simplicity and yet, elegance it strikes a mighty spear of fear into the heart. Of course the fanbase can be a bit (very) loopy at times, but that should not be taken into account when judging a game on its ability to scare.

And this game does it in spades. The atmosphere is very refreshing, with the lack of camera system being a warm welcome. The apprehension of flicking your flashlight on to check hallways because you're not sure if you did or did not hear an animatronic. Hell, you can't even relax in a damn minigame because even Plushtrap wants to mess you up. All in all, I think this is a very welcome addition to the series.

Screw the haters, play the damn game if you like being sent into cardiac arrest, and it just so happens that I bloody well do.

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4 changes up the formula drastically so, compared to it's predecessors. Playing as a child who was never taught monsters can't get you under the quilts instead takes it upon himself to defend his honor to be able stay up after bedtime by tackling the one true nightmarish horror, tetanus shots.

Ultimately the game runs more in line with FNAF 2, creating a pattern and never doing anything but that pattern for the entire game. It also feels much shorter by comparison to the previous games too, which likely isn't helped by the true ending hinting at things to come.

If you're a fan of the series, have bought every previous title and ERP in the Steam Community Discussions as your favorite Robot-Waifu, well. You've probably already bought it. Otherwise if you're tentative about embarking on this month's robot murder fest, I'd recommend watching few gameplay videos, but I must warn you in advance. The screaming manchild in the top-left corner isn't included with this purchase.

reviewText: I've never screamed at a jump scare before (but I do jump and in some cases gasp at them) until I played this game.  The game really catches you off guard with the scares, and I love it.  The atmosphere and ambience does a great job of setting the mood, and the animation is a lot more fluent than in the previous games.  Definitely a massive improvement in all aspects with the 4th of the series.  The physically checking the locations" gameplay style is a lot more entertaining and scary than the camera system from the previous games.  It's pretty startling to have to worry about the animatronics coming to you
date: but it's even more frightening to think that you might inadvertently run into them.  The addition of the mini game that allows you to skip the first two hours of the next night if you can beat it is awesome.  Who knew that "Red Light
recommended: Green Light" could ever be so tense?  Well done on this game!  I just hope I can steel my nerves well enough to beat it!"

reviewText: I'm a fan of the series, but this game doesn't seem as straight foward as the others. At the moment I'm literally finding it impossible to hear ANY sound cues that point to the fact that I'm about to die (headphones in, volume near max and yes I pause to listen). Everything is way too quiet UNTIL an animatronic scares me, and then at that point my ear drums are blown out! I'm not scared of anything in the game except unexpectedly hearing an extremely loud sound that will give me hearing loss. I like the concept and it seems good enough, but I'm having trouble enjoying it. It says I'm going to hear breathing, but I don't really hear anything. I feel like the audio needs to be corrected. Turn the jumpscare noise down, and the breathing" that is supposed to indicate animatroincs up. Also
date: I find the lack of full screen annoying. The game keeps crashing. It has even messed my screen up twice to where I couldn't see anything. I couldn't escape the game. The first time I had to shut off my computer
recommended: and the second I had to close it and unlock it. It seems to have a lot of problems
hoursPlayed: and when I feel they're fixed or I better understand the knows cues/get over having my eardrums blown out... I will like the game
voteText: but right now... I really don't. I feel as if these problems are addressed then this could probably be one of the best in the series."

reviewText:
Are you Nightmare Freddy for ready?

An amazing additional to the original quatriligy, fnaf 4 takes a fantastic approach to a whole new level, taking an original mechanic to the game and adding another. In this installment of the franchise, Scott (The creater/maker) took out the camera system and added a old mechanic of checking the doors with a light.
Pros: a good and challenging game to scare your socks off!
Cons: Takes an amount of patience to succeed and leaves many questions unanswered. (Who is the purple guy etc.)
On a scale of 1-10 I'd say its a high 8
Do i recommend it? YES.

reviewText:
It's been quite a long time since I had played a Five Nights at Freddys. This game is so... There are no words to describe how scary, eerie and most of all how awesome it is. Although, on my computer (which is a Toshiba Sattelite Dual Core Intel(R) Processor) it is a little skippy. Though after defragging it it's smooth as butter. Anyways. This game is the masterpiece of Five Nights at Freddys. Why do I say this? Well first off, I mayorly underestimated this game, which in turn this game scared the sh!t outta me! Second off, I had never played a game where I'm a kid in a house, trying to survive freaks of nature on my bed, plushtrap, Bonnie and Chica at the doors breathing, oh and foxy that rage master, and finally that stupid cupcake that Chica throws at my face. Third Off, the game mechanics are mimics of Five Nights at Candys, but Five Nights at Freddys 4 mimics it perfectly. So good job Scott Cawthon! Just remember (for anyone reading) that this is a horror rage game. Enjoy the game as much as I do.


EDIT: NO WAIT DON'T PRESS BUY!!! PLEASE.
Just don't. This game sucks, it's laggy and unplayable!! It's too hard and its jumpscares are PREDICTABLE. DON'T.BUY.THIS.GAME!!!

reviewText:
I died and yelled within 6 minutes despite trying as hard as possible to be a model toddler.
10/10 Srsly

EDIT: After I saw that a few people actually saw this review, I will serious it up a bit.
This is arguably the best Five Nights at Freddys game. Many people have gripes with the entire franchise, and they are entitled to their opinion. I do in fact wish to defend this game against the haters. Almost all of the haters fail to recognise this one thing: FNAF is a niche franchise. FNAF for all intents and purposes created its genre, and when I say this I am completely disregarding the MANY thousands of god-awful point and click scary" games that are in all actuality interactive storybooks with 2 cheap jumpscares and noises downloaded from freesound.org. FNAF practically created the standard for point-and-click horror games. It was the first to make a point and click actually scary. When I say scary
date: keep in mind everybody is scared of different things. FNAF 1 came out when its developer was in a bad place. It was the game that revitalized his career
recommended: and he loves doing this. To the people claiming he is milking his cash cow
hoursPlayed: just no. Scott loves doing this
voteText: let him do it. Also
votesHelpful: which is very cheap in a market FLOODED with $60 launch titles. He could stand to get away with at least twice what he charges yet he keeps them cheap. Not a milker. Now if you dislike the repetitive gameplay
votesTotal: realize that LOTS of games are repetitive. I once got to talk to a lead dev on the team that made Halo:CE. He said every game at its core is a 5 to 30 second experience repeated indefinitely. COD is like this
votesFunny: FNAF is like this
commentsCount: Halo is like this
column16: Battlefield is like this
column17:
etc. FNAF is not bad for being somewhat repetitive. It cant just wildly change how its played a dozen times. It sticks to a tried and true formula that works. But of course you wont like a game if you dont like the core gameplay. Duh.

TLDR:
FNAF is a game that PRACTICALLY invented its genre. It provided a high standard for games of its type
column18: and FNAF is a fun game series that had 4 unique titles that are all worth their money IMO. This one is the best personally."

reviewText:
Gratulation!

Dieses Spiel ist mit Abstand das Unheimlichste in der gesamten Serie. Die Atmosphäre ist düster und beklemmend, die Jumpscares besser eingebaut; allgemein ist das Spiel viel flüssiger was natürlich auf die Nerven schlägt.

Ganz zu schweigen von der neuen Mechanik: Man muss genau hinhören! Und genau dieser Umstand macht das Spiel viel nervenaufreibender als seine Vorgänger. ''Soll ich das Licht anmachen?'' ''War das ein Roboter, oder spielt mir mein Gehör ein Streich?'' Man muss weniger beachten (keine Kameras, Musikbox, etc.), dennoch muss man die einzelnen Aspekte im Spiel genau anschauen bzw. man muss genau hinhören, denn sonst lebt man nicht lange.
Dies sind nur einige Dinge, die einem fortwährend begleiten. Ganz zu schweigen, das die Jumpscares echt gut sind (ich bin selber beinahe vom Stuhl gefallen).

Für Fans der Serie ein definitives Must-Have

10/10


This game is definitely one of the scariest games in the franchise. The atmosphere is dark and nightmarish, the jumpscares are a more unexpected; in general this game plays much more nerve wracking.

The new machanics are just great. You really need to listen carefully! '' This game bases only on the sounds which gets more and more stressful through the night. '' Shall I flash my light? Was that a animatronic or just something else?'' All these questions went through my mind when I played this game.
There isn't much to do in this game. Just check the closet, bed and the hallways. But that's the tricky part. It's plays slower than the other games and you start to think more and more about this situation which results in getting you more scared. And as I mentioned before, you need to listen closely. Failures aren't tolerated in this game. And the Jumpscares...some don't like it, but I think they're really good and scary in this game...hell, I've just fell of my chair when I got jumpscared^^.

For fans of the serie a must have!

10/10

reviewText:
SPOILER ALERT!
Tried one night and already went to review this game.

Pros
1. The game has way better graphics than previous ones. And you can defnitely see it from System Requirements. I got easy 60 FPS, but still better graphics, what make jumpscares more 3D.
2. Amazing Title Screen! The best in the series (so far lol)
3. Price. I know it's not the cheapest one, but I was really worried that it might be 10€, but thank god it was 7,99€.
4. Gameplay. I like this child's home thingie. I disliked it when I saw trailer, but after I played awhile (and watched Youtube vids ofc) I started to like it
5. Very scary. Scariest one in the series. Jumpscare actually scared the crap out of me -_- And atmosphere feels like you're watching your childhood nightmare.

Yeah, positives are over, this game has many flaws and I hope Scott patch them soon so I can update this review.

Cons:
1. Sounds. Don't take me wrong, sound effects are really spooky and jumpscares has scary sound again, but seriously? This breathing thing kinda ruins game experience. My headset is very loud, even with low volume so I need to keep it volume 2%, because for example gun sounds from CSGO are very loud! But this is main problem in this game. Jumpscare volume is way too loud and I can't hear animatronic's breathing because volume is too low. I can't turn it higher as jumpscares would kill my ears :( Yes, I know game's listening feature, but I can't hear any sounds at all. I hope Scott patches this thing. Because this thing made me kill ESC button.
2. It's windowed fullscreen. Uh, not good.
3. I said price was the good thing, but it's also bad thing, because I almost feel that I wasted 8 euros.
4. It was rushed like FNAF3. Coincidence? I don't think so.
5. I'm still confused what I supposed to do!
6. Story is great as usual, BUT! It feels like it's nothing to do with basic story. This basically just says that player is victim of Bite of 87. Yep, I warned you. Spoiler Alert. I hope upcoming DLC does something. Because if not looks like we need two more games to tell whole story, if movie doesn't count.

Don't take me wrong. I don't hate this game. I like it so far. But I'm little bit disappointed. But I hope Scott fixes flaws with patch and make October's DLC very interesting. I will update review when patch and DLC comes out :)

7/10

Have Fun with Plushtrap!

reviewText:
This is probably the scariest installment yet, which is why it's a shame it's marred by some technical issues and the difficulty curve seems...wonky. I played to Night 2. For some reason on my system at least, there are a lot of strange delays in the beginning of the night. It takes several seconds for the flashlight to turn on and the screens to load, and it's a little disorienting and throws off the pace. As well, when the first night ended, my computer kind of went into hysterics, but that might be because of the full screen bug (which I won't harp on since Scott already addressed it).

The big thing for me is the difficulty. I'm pretty sure I beat Night 1 through sheer luck. I can't figure out the pattern to anything. The audio cues are too scarce a lot of the time, and there just doesn't feel like there's enough feedback for what you're doing right and wrong. The other games I could figure out fairly well.

These are all minor things in the long run that, if fixed, would make the game perfect. The atmosphere is great. The shortened screams make the jump scares far more frightening. The setting is actually a lot WORSE than the security offices from before. Having to move around adds a whole new layer. It's a scary experience, but it gets watered down so fast because it's so hard to figure out exactly what to do where. Maybe it's just me, and I'm missing something. I've heard you can hear breathing but I've tried several strategies and can't quite find one that works perfectly. Things seem a lot more random. Sometimes nothing happens until 3AM and sometimes Bonnie is waiting for me the second time I check his door 20 seconds in.

reviewText: In Two Hours at Freddy Krueger's you play as the all powerful Door Closer who seeks to open and shut the doors of his bedroom as many times as possible before 6 am. Your housemates become infuriated at the incessant door slamming all throughout the night and come to yell at you and put you to sleep. They're especially angry because when they try to talk to you, you flash a bright light in their face which disorients them momentarily. Otherwise, there is no objective in this game.

reviewText: In my opinion, this was the scariest game in the series. The first game had an extremely creepy vibe to it, the second one seemed to not have that same vibe. But the third game brought it back, somewhat, and this game just blows it out of the water. And I like that it relies more on auditory queues this time. Taking the security cameras away and putting you in the place of a frightened child seems to give off more of the creepiness, because it's harder to tell when to expect to be jumpscared than the last three games. I won't give any spoilers, but some mysteries are still left unsolved. But hey, we've still got the DLC coming on Halloween to look forward to!

reviewText:
The initial concept of this game was something that bugged me. I didn't think that this game could be scary, especially after my disappointment with FNAF 3. Boy was I wrong!

Cameras are no longer a thing and your only way of knowing where the animatronics are is by listening out for the audio queues and, to me, this was a brilliant design choice. Having to stand there in the doorway, carefully listening out for breathing to make sure it is safe outside is something that is truly terrifying and puts me on edge. The fear of not knowing what you will see when you flick your flashlight on is amazing.

This game has given me some of the biggest scares I have had in a long time and this is without a doubt the scariest entry in the series yet.

reviewText:
What a game! What a game indeed...Now, I have about 10 friends that have this game so far.
The game itself is very entertaining, and by FAR my most favorite in the series at the moment.
Scott has done a wonderful job with his games (With exception of FNaF 3 in my opinion) so far with such a small amount of time.
I as a person almost live off this game and it's theories that people make in the lore.
Although the game is good, the lore... IS BETTER!
There are so many twists and turns throughout the game
I have a little table here for you with what I rate everything separately.

Part of the Game        Score                Mechanics        10/10                Design        9/10                Sound        8.5/10
Mechanics: I loved the mechanics in this 4th installment to the FNaF franchise. The flashlight usage, child in his room, listening at the door. It all fit in so well with it's atmosphere. Only thing was that the camera idea was gone... It was the thing that really set the feeling for the games, and it isn't a bad thing necessarily! It is just something crucial to the past games.

Design: The new Nightmare" design to these animatronics have me hooked. They are something new and revolution to the feeling of "scary" that Five Nights at Freddy's has introduced so far. The rush of being jump-scared was enough
date: but this step up from that with a new Hellish look to these already freaky things was the tip of the iceberg to FNaF.\n\nSound: Alright
recommended: the sounds of the game were all creepy and atmospheric. There was a few things that made me a little angry... the footsteps of your character were literally re-used sounds from Foxy's run in the first game
hoursPlayed: the sounds are still a little to quiet for me to be honest

votesHelpful: I know it made it seem as if they were Nightmare-like with there voices being mashed together
votesTotal:
but I would've preferred a deeper pitched roar compared to a loud scream.

There is still one thing that I haven't fully gotten into...

The Lore / Story lineThis game leaves so many new questions unanswered compared to the ones that could've been answered. The Bite of 87 could've been this poor child
votesFunny: or possibly another from a later time or different building. The Purple Guy Easter egg could mean a few different things that I won't get into right now. I love the franchise's lore and I always will
commentsCount: and I will also continue theorizing as much as I can!\n\nNow To / About ScottMy friends tell me that you've made too many mistakes. Mistakes that you can't make up for. Little things that make no sense when compared to things. But I refuse to believe it. Every LITTLE thing that you've done must have some sort of reasoning behind it. I refuse to believe that you make a mistake knowingly or lazily. Show everyone that their wrong your own way

reviewText:
Gotta be honest, I wasn't so sure of the quality of this 4th installment in the beginning. I still think the original character designs are, in a way, creepier than the Nightmare designs.

The moment I watched the trailer, I had a mixed reaction:

+ A part of me liked the idea of an innovative environment, while bringing back some FNAF 1 mechanics like the double side doors to close. I also loved the idea of slight movement being possible and the possibility to turn around for more than ~90°. In a moment of lucidity I also realized the animations were actually worked upon this time, and I was happy to see that the Jumpscares went back to the quality of the first game (loud, terrifying sound and shaky screen) and upped it to eleven with the animation itself as you can actually see them grab you, and that's important as it increases immersion in the game.

- Another part of me recoiled at the idea of the house environment, which really isn't Freddy's"

reviewText:
(If TL;DR, you can watch my first impressions here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QAOhb0WmpGA

FNAF4 is another sequel diluting the golden intrinsic value of the original FNAF and what it was all about.  Perhaps I'm disenchanted because I've played them all and each one after the 2nd sequel seemed unnecessary and redundant to my vapid, jaded disposition.

The same game mechanic of doors and lights are back with bitter vengeance along with a very unwelcomed partner: audio cues in the form of undead breathing.  That's right, you have to listen and shut the door praying whatever animatronic is after you gets bored and slinks away.  On the week this game was initially released, it was total luck if you heard any breathing at all before hesitating to shine your light down a hallway or shut the door.  Shutting the door when nobody was there garnered unwanted attention and shining the light on any character at your door meant you were as good as dead.  Imagine the frustration maximizing your computer's volume to hear no breathing, then succumb to the loudest jump scare of your life. Luckily this problem has since been fixed, so maybe you won't go half as deaf with headphones now as you would have previously.  I hope you aren't afraid of the tiny Freddy's on your bed, because you have to do the opposite and shine your light on them without hesitation to scare them off.  Foxy is as unbearable as ever, thanks to the screech he offers upon finding him in the closet for the first time or when he's neglected.  Shut the closet doors and count to 10 to neutralize him, if you don't, Foxy will be the last character you see come out of the closet (closeted homosexuality joke quota fulfilled).  There's so many more details to go into but put simply is your timing and prioritization is off by even a millisecond you will die.

On a tangent, the plushtrap mini-game seems out of place in this game.  It's not part of the main story, and although it beating it lets you skip 2 hours on the following night, I could never grasp the idea of how to win this based on auditory cues.

The plot is as ambiguous as ever providing little details between every weeknight in quasi-eight-bit cut scenes.  You play as a boy who doesn't like Freddy Fazbear's anymore after seeing something bad go on there (what exactly you saw isn't made very clear).  Each night counts down to your inevitable birthday at Freddy's and as a result of your older brother and his friends, your head gets lodged in Fredbear's mouth where you are crushed to death.  (Don’t even get me started on what happens on nights 6 and 7, I’ll hit my character limit).  Many players initially thought this was the bite of 1987, but an Easter egg in one of the Atari-esque plot scenes reveals that it might actually be another incident that occurred in 1983.  Turning on the television in your house reveals a Fazbear TV show or commercial whose copyright is 1983, but we may never know for sure what this means until another sequel or DLC comes out for this franchise.  -Oh dear god, take a break Scott Cawthon!  This is the fourth game you've made in the length of a whole year.  Have you ever heard of taking a break or doing things in moderation?  I certainly guess not.

In the grand scheme of things, you might have better enjoyment watching somebody else play this game on a YouTube video or when you’re hanging out with your friends.  Getting this game at this point in time seems like a pretty nonsensical decision, especially since the original was better.

reviewText:
The Gameplay:

The gameplay is actually quite complicated compared to the other games. In this one, you can scare the animatronics away using your flashlight, which I believe has unlimited use. When you check a door, you must wait a couple seconds before deciding whether you will use the flashlight, or hold the door shut. You must hold the door shut if you hear any breathing whatsoever, until you hear no more. However, if you close the door while an animatronic is at the END of the hall, it will bring them next to the door, and the next time you use the flashlight on the door, it will jumpscare you (which, by the way, is about 100 times scarier than the other ones, just a heads up). Also, when you close the door, you must HOLD it shut, instead of letting it stay closed like before, and since you can only check on one thing at time, you  cannot keep multiple doors closed at once. You must also check behind you, where the little Freddies lurk. The little Freddies are actually very simple. They will come over time, so you must eventually constantly check behind you. With the Freddies, you simply hold your flashlight on until all of them disappear. Don't be afraid to check behind you when you need to, as this game is meant to be taken quite slowly as opposed to the games prior. I haven't actually encountered Foxy, but I've been told you must check the closet when your flashlight flickers. Then you must shine the light in, and if he is there, you hold it shut.
The Atmosphere:

Oh God, the atmosphere. The game's atmosphere definitely is terrifying for a couple reasons. First, there is no Phone Guy to comfort you. I always felt that PG was very comforting, as at least it wasn't silent. In fact, I didn't even want to play the first one on night 4 because he dies" on it. Also the noise of the fun running. There is still the fan (which is purple
hoursPlayed: the lighting. There is no light whatsoever
voteText: except for the flashlight. No hall light

it's pitch black until you turn on the flashlight.
The Graphics:

There's really not much to say about the graphics. They're pretty much the same as all the others

10/10 would check the door again.

reviewText:
The scary thing about FNAF isn't the animatronics or the story; it's how it isn't too over-the-top. And that just makes it creepier. Honestly, it borders on psychological horror, basically, you know you are going to die. A lot. So no reason trying to go all silent hill. FNAF 4 really embodies that. It does it's best to fill you with paronoia and fear, rather than just jumping up in your face (they only do that when they kill you)


You will die.
A lot.
Seriously, it makes Dark Souls look like a Kitten.
Do not try to make this game without a jumpscare.
I died at least 4 times on the second night.
And I am still on it, so it could be more.

reviewText: This game has to be the best and scariest game of the series. It is also the game that offers the most of all the games. I feel like I can play this game for hours and never get bored, and also never not be scared. I love the new 'Fun with Plushtrap' minigame that allows you to skip 2 hours in the night, that was an amazing idea by Scott. This game focuses on hearing (Headphones are recommended as they can help tell which side an animatronic is at). To keep away the animatronics you must listen for their breathing. If you hear the breathing you must close the door as quickly as possible until they leave. If you don't hear breathing, you flash the light to scare them away down the hall. Since the game is based so heavily on listening an waiting, it makes it even scarier when an animatronic jumpscares you. The game also has the most nights out of any game, but a custom night would have been amazing. The game handle's really well, has amazing graphics, sounds and music, and has you gasping and screaming almost every second of the way. I highly recommend buying this game f you love the FNaF series and/or horror games.

reviewText:
For those of you who complain about the few issues that FNAF 4 has at the moment.....

Remember that this is the first day that it has been released to the public. It will take a few days for any possible bugs to be worked out. Scott works very hard on these games, and you can't expect them to be 100% perfectly smooth running when they first come out. The only way to find problems is to have people test the system. A great example is the full screen issue which Scott is already working on.


Long story short, yes it has a few very minor issues, but know that Scott can get them straightened out, and once he does, Five Nights At Freddy's 4 will be the best game in the series so far.

10/10 I would recommend this game to friends, but I would suggest that they bear with it till the bugs are worked out (which hopefully won't be long).


Can't wait to see what the DLC has in store for us.

reviewText:
10/10 Really scary game in my books. But I'm kinda iffy on playing it, I really don't wanna feel like I wasted 8 dollars by just having it sitting in my Library, so I'm just gonna wait until the Breathing is made a bit louder, because it is really hard to hear it. So until the bugs are fixed, I'll only play it with people around because I'm bad with scary games. GJ SCOTT.

Helpful Part:
I suggest getting the game. If you're gonna buy the game, don't judge it yet. It was only released yesterday, and people are hating on it already; Bugs this, Bugs that, this isn't working, that isn't loud enough. PEOPLE PLEASE, give Scott a chance to work out any standing bugs. I would recomemend waiting a bit before getting the game so you get the best out of it.
Look at other reviews before buying the game. If people are saying bad things about it, it would be best not to get it until things are worked out.
Wait a bit before using your flashlight. If you hear ANYTHING you should close the door for a few seconds, then open and flash your light. If you are not good with jumpscares, but really wanna get the game, watch videos to learn the best way to avoid the scares, or be like me, and have a friend or family member with you while playing, it might make you feel better.

reviewText:
This game. I can't even begin to describe how good this is.

First off, for my piece of crap computer, the game ran GOOD. That doesn't normally happen.

Anyway, let's get to the cons.
- For me, the game starts to pause when you load a new door.
- The tips seem to be in the way, even though you can disable them.

Pros!
+Runs very smooth.
+Nice transitions to each different area.
+A new and very scary apporach to the original point and click game.
+Scared the balls out of me unlike any of the other games (Sorry, it was just too predictable).
+Nice atmosphere. Again, scared the balls out of me.

For now, that is about all I can say! I rate the game 9.9/10, only because of the very, VERY minor issues that I experienced personally.

Thank you for another GREAT experience.

~takeo9

reviewText: awesome,awesome,awesome,AWESOME, AND AAAAAAAAAAAAWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEESSSSSSSSSSSSSSOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!this game is amazing!it's is such an improvement and this game proves that change can be very good.you see,there isnt any cameras,but you can more or less free roam,mostly around the  room.also this game reveals a lot about the story.i wont spoil it but i will say this,you will notice that unlike the other 3 games,mainly the 3rd,the description for this game reveals nothing involving the story.there is a reason for that.i went in this expecting a game that didn't have anything to do with the story and may or may not suck and what i got was an awesome game with a very interesting story that also answers a LOT of questions about the story of all 4 games.it's like the second game where you can find out a lot about the story of the games,you just have to look hard enough.i can't wait for the DLC.scott if you ever see this,i must tell you i am very happy with you and your games.you made 4 games in 1 year,and they all were amazing.i played your other games,and they were very good,too.you are awesome,and i cant wait to see what your next game will be after fnaf.

reviewText:
I have fnaf1 and 2 on my iPad and they're fantastic. However, even if I played alone with headphones on in those games, they just didn't scare me that much. Well, not half as much as this one. This is by far my favourite game right now. When you watch the videos of fnaf4 on youtube, it definitely isn't as scary as playing it by yourself. So far I'm on night 3 and Chica has killed me twice. I almost jumped out of my skin both times! Even when Foxy was in the closet, it still scared me!

My rating: 8/10
+Graphics are good
+Sound effects make the atmosphere tense
+Jumpscares are intense
+Breathing sounds are clear

-Black bars either side of the screen in the main menu
-Your volume must be loud to hear breathing
-Some problems broadcasting gameplay

Overall, I recommend this game. Even though you might get a little deaf after this, it's definitely worth it!

reviewText: Well, it's scary, for sure and being a horror game, I think that is all you really want! Unlike in the other games, you can't really anticipate when the jumpscare is coming, so they stay fresh and get you every time! Althoug sometimes the jumpscare has to load and the screen goes black for a while, in which case you know EXACTLY what is about to happen... Whcih brings me onto my first complaint - loading times. Each night takes from 30 seconds to a full 5 minutes to load, aswell as in game animations, which take about 10 seconds to load at the start of a night. It may not seem like much, but whith the speed of the animatronics you need every second to put towards keeping them away... Whcih brings me onto my second issue: the game gets too hard too quickly. Night 1 and 2 were quite good, but then at night three you are thrown into a literal torrent of jumpscares. I am a very casual gamer and, as such, struggle trying to get past 1am in night 3! I think a difficulty setting should be incorporated (e.g. an easy, medium and hard) so people like me can finish the game. Finally, for some reason, the game won't fill my full screen, even when I press F11. This is only a minor issue. However, despite this, I will continue to try my best to complete it, even if I can't get past night 3, for the brilliant, smooth gameplay that is new to FNaF. I look forward to the DLC and can't wait to find out everything about the backstory! Overall, a very good game that meets up and exceeds standards that you may want to play if your computer is beefier than mine (which isn't too great...) and you can take the jumpscares! Edit: Well, Scott has fixed the full screen isuue! Now i just have to click 'continue' to see if it loads faster! Oh dear.... Ehem, no that that is a problem, having to play it or anything.... DEFINITELY not because it is so scary or anything, he he, erm..

reviewText:
UPDATE: Since the changes to the audio levels of this game, it has become a hell of a lot more enjoyable to play. This is easily in the top 2 of my favourite FNAF games. Still to be completed, but night 5 isn't a walk in the park right now!

The only thing I'm not enjoying about this game so far is that there's two extremes to the volumes: On the one hand you're raising your awareness for this supposed 'breathing' noise I can't seem to make out, and on the other, said risen awareness plus extremely loud jumpscare equals  a really bad headache.

As the game stands right now, it's pretty awesome, I'm impressed with this one, and is well on the way to being the best in the series - the graphics are awesome, the concept is awesome, everything about the look and feel of the game so far is awesome, but the flashlight sticks sometimes which sucks, and I'm not willing to risk my hearing just so I can deficate myself. If the other aspects of the game are good enough, you don't need loud noises to scare people - If you want that, I suggest any horror story mod on Garry's Mod.

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4. The final chapter of the Five Nights at Freddy's... quadrilogy, I guess you'd call it, unless you'd count the Five Nights movie coming out some time soon. Scott has always managed to create, well, not necessarily good since 3 was kind of meh, but interesting games with a neat little backstory to them that webs the games together into an interesting little plot. With the pretty good 1, the less impressive but still decent 2, and the kind of meh 3 that at least was a lot better than it could've been, Scott managed to create a massive fanbase around the little franchise that could, and yeah, I have to admit I am part of that group. I was looking forward to this game and I was saving up to get the last game on Halloween since I enjoyed the last 3 enough and liked the franchise, but apparently we decided that Halloween was on July 23rd and Scott released it then. So yeah, I had to frantically collect some money and got it a month or two later. Then I got distracted by Metal Gear Solid 5 and I kind of still am distracted by that now, but I played this on and off to assemble a review like I did for the last 3. So what did I think? Let's see.

STORY: You're an unnamed kid. Have no idea what he's named, so I'll call him Bob. In the middle of the night, Bob is woken up from his slumber and finds that animatronics are trying to get him, so you have to deal with all of them from 12AM to 6AM. That's the basic gameplay plot, and while it is neat that this franchise steps away from anything pizzeria related, that bit is kind of lame, though granted, I don't have as many problems with this than I do with Mike Schmidt going back each night to a job where he could be killed and stuffed into a suit and other problems with the general pizzeria problems. There are those 8-bit minigames between each night, which tells the story of the kid you play as and his bully brother, which is a bit more interesting and tells a lot about the lore. Overall, same kind of underwhelming plot held up by the decent lore that keeps it worth playing.

GAMEPLAY: No more cameras here in Five Nights 4, which is kind of lame and I do really miss them, and I think Scott could've perfected the system if he did it again, but I get why he didn't do that. You have to check the two hallways on either side of your room for animatronics. You flash your flashlight down the hallway to check and see if any of the animatronics are down there. If they're at the end of the hall, they'll screw off and you'll be fine for now. If they're right at your door, you will get jumpscared. In order to prevent this, you need to listen for any breathing to see if they're there. If yes, you have to shut the door and wait for them to go. If not, flash the light. Foxy will sometimes sneak his way into your closet if you don't scare him off, in which case you have to do the same thing there. You have to check your bed behind you as well in order to prevent Freddy from manifesting and attacking you. In later nights you'll get a single animatronic who is incredibly aggressive and you have to prevent him from him getting in. The gameplay is the tensest it gets since FN2 and it isn't as aggrevating as it is in 2, which is nice. I still think 2 is a bit more fun than this, but I don't care necessarily as long as it's good, which I say it is.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE: I can't tell the framerate on this game since the Steam Overlay that I use to check with these games doesn't work with this game for some reason, but it runs smoothly enough. The game looks decent enough, it isn't exactly a high quality 4K resolution game or anything like that, but it does the job well enough.

CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: You have six, kind of seven animatronics to deal with, though most nights you only have to deal with 3 or 4 and the others are just one basically. The usual four animatronics; Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy, are in here, they look pretty freaky, Scott went all out with their designs here, and they are creepy. There's also a Nightmare Golden Freddy and an animatronic simply named Nightmare, who are variants of the Freddy design. They are both pretty damn creepy, but I think one is just a recoloring of the other. Oh yeah, and there's a cupcake that kills you if you just stand around and do nothing. ♥♥♥♥ing emberassing way to go, I know. One thing that makes sense but I still kind of miss is that Phone Guy didn't make an appearance here, I liked the aspect of figuring out what basically to do from his phone calls instead of that lazy popup that told you what to do and how to do it. There isn't really any voice acting unless you count the jumpscare noises, but I think those are just modified versions of stock sound effects.

EXTRAS: When you beat the main 5 nights, you get access to Night 6. Once you beat that you unlock a Nightmare mode and some extras. There is a hidden 20/20/20/20 mode that you get if you type 20202020" in the game
recommended: I'm still on Night 6. xD Scott'll add some stuff on Halloween

reviewText: This game is so amazing, the graphics got better and so did the jumpscares, but the atmosphere is amazing. It creates a feeling of tension and suspension of when the jumpscare is going to happen. Not just working at a pizza place, but in a scared child's bedroom. Five Nights at Freddy's 4 creates the feeling of being a little kid, scared of monsters in your closet. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a nice jumpscare (;

reviewText:
Overall rating:

9/10

Description:

a strategic survival horror with a huge fan base. it has a deciptivly simple design and lots of jumpscares

Expected completion time:

2-5 hours, so very short

For those who like:

horror games, or something a bit different

Replayability?:

depends, some fans will play over and over, others will want to punch their monitor by the time its finished

Value for money?:

yes, it's a short game but the price if fair for what you get

Collectables?:

no, but scott is famouse for hiding many, many easter eggs in his games. but finding them is extrremely difficult

Things of note:

not everyone will enjoy this game. it's like vegiemite, people are either going to love it or hate it. fans of the series will be VERY satisfied with this game

reviewText:
I have seen many things already, i find this game scary as hell and  i try not to jump and scream but i do. Call me a baby if you will, The breathing when you go to the door is deep and evil and it creeps me out, there are allot of outdoor noises that can confuse me but that makes the game allot more fun to play.

Scott, congrats i really enjoyed this series and from what i have played so far, this one is my number 1 out the 4. I hope to see more games from you after this, don't dissapear.

Now, time to talk about some pros and cons


Pros:
The atmospher is chilling and dark adding to the thrill of this game, no complaints

Sound is wonderful and very chilling, i have seen no problems when it comes to sound

The jumpscares are great and new, detail on the characters is wonderful

Anmation of the characters are smooth and chilling

i could go on  but i will keep this short


Cons:

Switching from area to area can be slowl when you first begin but it speeds up quickly

full screen is a bit wack but easy to fix

.............................................................

thats really it, im sure all of the errors will be fixed, so people who complain need to chill...you try making a game and make it work, see how well you do. I have found most of the negativity to be false, i have little to no problem with anything that is said to be wrong

reviewText: I was very excited when I found out that this game had been released early. After booting it up and playing for a few minutes, I discovered a few bugs. Upon booting the game, instead of going into fullscreen like I assume it's supposed to, it instead began running in a window and changed my entire computer's resolution. Second, after booting up and fixing the resolution, the game told me to turn my volume up until I could hear the sound of crickets in the background. I wound up turning it all the way to max volume before I finally heard them, and even then just barely. And finally, a slight issue during gameplay. When the animation played that showed the player running to the doors, the game would freeze for a few seconds. I also encountered a similar problem when trying to look at the bed. However, instead of showing the animation right away, the game froze for a solid fifteen seconds before it finally registered.\n\nIn my opinion, Scott should not have released this game early. Then he likely would have found and fixed these problems. I still recommend this game, but only after Scott fixes these bugs with an update.

reviewText: Everything I expected and WAY more. I knew the graphics wouldn't be the best because of Scott making it completely 3D but I was really impressed with that, including the stuff you could instantly pick up in just the first night. I imagined Scott would've gone with the normalities, but he really threw that out with the finale. I found myself completely terrified from the moment I opened up the game. I give props to Scott for creating a genre changing franchise. I've have nightmares for years. Thanks Scott for all the work you've put into with these games.\n\nI highly recomment this game to those who believe that they wouldn't be terrified by 'silly robots' jumpscaring you.

reviewText:
Night 1, Listen's for Chica shines flashlight, see's Chica, shuts the door, listens for breathing, hears nothing opens door, another pair of underwear ruined.

This game is a lot tougher than previous FNAF games but I do have my moans about it which I think need to be established.

*I have yet to hear anything breathing, only noises I hear are the crickets and the robot occasionally make noises, I can't advance because I never know when I'm safe to open the door and shine my flashlight or move to another door.
*Screen resolution isn't a major issue though dissapointing.
*Seems to not respond for 5 seconds before entering a new night which baffles me, then goes back to normal.

Overall as it stands 7.5/10 probably the scariest game out of them all but the concept of listening for them and for me not being able to hear is a real issue, and I do have a decent set of sound cancelling headphones

reviewText: After a slight disappointment with Five Nights at Freddy's 3 (not that it was a bad game, it just wasn't as good as the other two or as scary), Scott Cawthon has managed to get himself and his creations back into our nightmares with his latest and last addition to the Five Nights at Freddy's franchise. However, the main action within the game does not take place within the pizzeria like the last three games did, instead, it takes place in a normal house that belongs to a child whose story is told as the game progresses. But, this change of location is refreshing and it works really well. The normality of the setting helps set in the fear factor for the player, and can make them believe that they are susceptible to attacks such as these in their own home. The first game especially was lauded for taking place in a familiar setting for players (a restaurant with animatronics), but this is only a setting which is familiar to some players. I myself am British, so I am not familiar with animatronic pizza restaurants, but the setting here opens up the fear factor to EVERYONE. I haven't played the entire game, so don't ask me what gets answered and what doesn't. And if one part of the Five Nights at Freddy's mystery isn't solved, never fear! Scott Cawthon will be releasing a major update on Halloween 2015, which presumably may have a new setting to play in.\n\nOverall, this is a fantastic game with a great deal of depth and thought having gone into it, and the scares most definitely are there. I don't want to spoil the game for you, go and play it and experience it for yourself!

reviewText:
Overall rating:

9/10

Description:

a strategic survival horror with a huge fan base. it has a deciptivly simple design and lots of jumpscares

Expected completion time:

2-5 hours, so very short

For those who like:

horror games, or something a bit different

Replayability?:

depends, some fans will play over and over, others will want to punch their monitor by the time its finished

Value for money?:

yes, it's a short game but the price if fair for what you get

Collectables?:

no, but scott is famouse for hiding many, many easter eggs in his games. but finding them is extrremely difficult

Things of note:

not everyone will enjoy this game. it's like vegiemite, people are either going to love it or hate it. fans of the series will be VERY satisfied with this game
