reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4. The final chapter of the Five Nights at Freddy's... quadrilogy, I guess you'd call it, unless you'd count the Five Nights movie coming out some time soon. Scott has always managed to create, well, not necessarily good since 3 was kind of meh, but interesting games with a neat little backstory to them that webs the games together into an interesting little plot. With the pretty good 1, the less impressive but still decent 2, and the kind of meh 3 that at least was a lot better than it could've been, Scott managed to create a massive fanbase around the little franchise that could, and yeah, I have to admit I am part of that group. I was looking forward to this game and I was saving up to get the last game on Halloween since I enjoyed the last 3 enough and liked the franchise, but apparently we decided that Halloween was on July 23rd and Scott released it then. So yeah, I had to frantically collect some money and got it a month or two later. Then I got distracted by Metal Gear Solid 5 and I kind of still am distracted by that now, but I played this on and off to assemble a review like I did for the last 3. So what did I think? Let's see.

STORY: You're an unnamed kid. Have no idea what he's named, so I'll call him Bob. In the middle of the night, Bob is woken up from his slumber and finds that animatronics are trying to get him, so you have to deal with all of them from 12AM to 6AM. That's the basic gameplay plot, and while it is neat that this franchise steps away from anything pizzeria related, that bit is kind of lame, though granted, I don't have as many problems with this than I do with Mike Schmidt going back each night to a job where he could be killed and stuffed into a suit and other problems with the general pizzeria problems. There are those 8-bit minigames between each night, which tells the story of the kid you play as and his bully brother, which is a bit more interesting and tells a lot about the lore. Overall, same kind of underwhelming plot held up by the decent lore that keeps it worth playing.

GAMEPLAY: No more cameras here in Five Nights 4, which is kind of lame and I do really miss them, and I think Scott could've perfected the system if he did it again, but I get why he didn't do that. You have to check the two hallways on either side of your room for animatronics. You flash your flashlight down the hallway to check and see if any of the animatronics are down there. If they're at the end of the hall, they'll screw off and you'll be fine for now. If they're right at your door, you will get jumpscared. In order to prevent this, you need to listen for any breathing to see if they're there. If yes, you have to shut the door and wait for them to go. If not, flash the light. Foxy will sometimes sneak his way into your closet if you don't scare him off, in which case you have to do the same thing there. You have to check your bed behind you as well in order to prevent Freddy from manifesting and attacking you. In later nights you'll get a single animatronic who is incredibly aggressive and you have to prevent him from him getting in. The gameplay is the tensest it gets since FN2 and it isn't as aggrevating as it is in 2, which is nice. I still think 2 is a bit more fun than this, but I don't care necessarily as long as it's good, which I say it is.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE: I can't tell the framerate on this game since the Steam Overlay that I use to check with these games doesn't work with this game for some reason, but it runs smoothly enough. The game looks decent enough, it isn't exactly a high quality 4K resolution game or anything like that, but it does the job well enough.

CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: You have six, kind of seven animatronics to deal with, though most nights you only have to deal with 3 or 4 and the others are just one basically. The usual four animatronics; Freddy, Bonnie, Chica, and Foxy, are in here, they look pretty freaky, Scott went all out with their designs here, and they are creepy. There's also a Nightmare Golden Freddy and an animatronic simply named Nightmare, who are variants of the Freddy design. They are both pretty damn creepy, but I think one is just a recoloring of the other. Oh yeah, and there's a cupcake that kills you if you just stand around and do nothing. ♥♥♥♥ing emberassing way to go, I know. One thing that makes sense but I still kind of miss is that Phone Guy didn't make an appearance here, I liked the aspect of figuring out what basically to do from his phone calls instead of that lazy popup that told you what to do and how to do it. There isn't really any voice acting unless you count the jumpscare noises, but I think those are just modified versions of stock sound effects.

EXTRAS: When you beat the main 5 nights, you get access to Night 6. Once you beat that you unlock a Nightmare mode and some extras. There is a hidden 20/20/20/20 mode that you get if you type 20202020" in the game

reviewText: This game is so amazing, the graphics got better and so did the jumpscares, but the atmosphere is amazing. It creates a feeling of tension and suspension of when the jumpscare is going to happen. Not just working at a pizza place, but in a scared child's bedroom. Five Nights at Freddy's 4 creates the feeling of being a little kid, scared of monsters in your closet. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes a nice jumpscare (;

reviewText: Scott If this the end I wish you well on the next gaming series you do. You did so great on this game series it breaks my heart to her the title of the game (which is Five Nights At Freddy's 4 The Final Chapter) and I remeber most of everyones reaction when the FIrst one came out and when I played it on my mobile device when bonnie popped up and scared the living daylight out if me I literally dropped my phone,  Then I found out you were making a 2nd game and I bought it the day it came out and the way you changed the game series it was mind blowing ive never seen any game developer do that I was mind blown. Then the 3rd one came and at this time this game became an internet sensation and i saw the trailer and literally said Shut up and take my money" and played it and found all the secrets and my brain was spinning I was going on google to see for anything. I was doing everything to find out the backstory to this great game I never did find it but i do hope it gets solved in the 4th and final one (even tho I hope its not the end). Then today July 24th 2015 I was going through my subscribtions and I see "Markiplier ARE YOU BRAVE ENOUGH? / Five Nights At Freddy's 4 - Part 1" and he said its the demo and I was like dangit then his 2nd episode came out and he said "its out NOW" I then ran to my computer and checked steam and it said "Five Nights At Freddy's 4 8.00$" I asked for it right away and started to play it. I was talking to a friend while playing and shined my left to the right door and saw Bonnie run away and closed the game and told my friend "I cant do this" and he started to laugh he then had to talk to his mom. I started to play I made it on night 2 I was shaking then the closet moved I went to it  and Foxy jumpscared me I started to shake so bad it looked like I was picking up a fever I was shacking so bad I beat the night and needed to take a breather I came back upstairs and wrought this giangantic review. So this giant review is more like a giant thank you to Scott because without him scary games wouldnt be as fun as they are im not that big on scary games but this game is so fun that I dont care how much I get scared so thanks Scott so much and good luck on your next game I will take a look at your next game you do but no mater waht you will be in my book of best game creator. GOOD LUCK SCOTT."

reviewText:
Night 1, Listen's for Chica shines flashlight, see's Chica, shuts the door, listens for breathing, hears nothing opens door, another pair of underwear ruined.

This game is a lot tougher than previous FNAF games but I do have my moans about it which I think need to be established.

*I have yet to hear anything breathing, only noises I hear are the crickets and the robot occasionally make noises, I can't advance because I never know when I'm safe to open the door and shine my flashlight or move to another door.
*Screen resolution isn't a major issue though dissapointing.
*Seems to not respond for 5 seconds before entering a new night which baffles me, then goes back to normal.

Overall as it stands 7.5/10 probably the scariest game out of them all but the concept of listening for them and for me not being able to hear is a real issue, and I do have a decent set of sound cancelling headphones

reviewText: five nights at freddys 3 was decent, but really the story is all i really took from it. But this, this is a whole new level. Amazing story that sticks with you, great animations, chilling atmosphere, and of course, the jumpscares. These jumpscares give little to no warning and can really surprise you. This game is very good at scaring with more than just jumpscares. but anticipation. Every time you turn on the flashlight you cringe. Everytime you look behind you and then turn around again, you want to momentarily turn down the volume. And just when you think you have a handle on the system, Scott throws a curveball to make you change how you play. Great game! Good job Scott and God bless!

reviewText: Though people say this is a boring game, I don't find it boring when every move I make is a deciding factor if I die or live (in-game of course this isn't Saw). I'm not supposed to be playing this game anyways because jumpscares are my worst enemy, but it's the fact that this game induces some real suspense is what makes this game so great. I couldn't get past Night 3 due to the sound cues being too low (and I did have a huge problem with how you have to listen very closely only to not being able to hear the sound cue and then blasted with that louddddd jumpscare.) But now I'm able to get through it easier, experimenting the sounds, and the update did help. I am extremely eager to see how this game will be when it's fully fixed up, but I still won't stop playing this game since it's honestly, in my opinion, amazing!

reviewText: I could feel my heart pounding in my chest. I turn around to check that nothing had crept up behind me while my back was turned. As my flaslight turns its beam onto my bed, somthing jumps off, to somewhere I didn't know. I turn back around to face the door on my left. I run over and peek out to listen for any sounds that might mean something was standing outside the door. I coudn't hear anything, and I turned on my flashlight. Somthing blue moves behind the corner, and I slam the door shut tight. And then I made the worst mistake I had ever made. I opened the door to peek outside, to see if it had gone, and in nearly one second somthing jumps at me out of the hallway, with a metalic screech. I felt the huge mass throw me to the ground, the tight jaws clamping onto my face, the sharp teeth cutting through my skin. I screamed for help but none came. I knew it was over.

reviewText:
The Gameplay:

The gameplay is actually quite complicated compared to the other games. In this one, you can scare the animatronics away using your flashlight, which I believe has unlimited use. When you check a door, you must wait a couple seconds before deciding whether you will use the flashlight, or hold the door shut. You must hold the door shut if you hear any breathing whatsoever, until you hear no more. However, if you close the door while an animatronic is at the END of the hall, it will bring them next to the door, and the next time you use the flashlight on the door, it will jumpscare you (which, by the way, is about 100 times scarier than the other ones, just a heads up). Also, when you close the door, you must HOLD it shut, instead of letting it stay closed like before, and since you can only check on one thing at time, you  cannot keep multiple doors closed at once. You must also check behind you, where the little Freddies lurk. The little Freddies are actually very simple. They will come over time, so you must eventually constantly check behind you. With the Freddies, you simply hold your flashlight on until all of them disappear. Don't be afraid to check behind you when you need to, as this game is meant to be taken quite slowly as opposed to the games prior. I haven't actually encountered Foxy, but I've been told you must check the closet when your flashlight flickers. Then you must shine the light in, and if he is there, you hold it shut.
The Atmosphere:

Oh God, the atmosphere. The game's atmosphere definitely is terrifying for a couple reasons. First, there is no Phone Guy to comfort you. I always felt that PG was very comforting, as at least it wasn't silent. In fact, I didn't even want to play the first one on night 4 because he dies" on it. Also the noise of the fun running. There is still the fan (which is purple
hoursPlayed: the lighting. There is no light whatsoever
voteText: except for the flashlight. No hall light
votesHelpful: nothing. Whenever you go to check something
votesTotal:
it's pitch black until you turn on the flashlight.
The Graphics:

There's really not much to say about the graphics. They're pretty much the same as all the others
votesFunny: with maybe a slight enhancement here and there
commentsCount: but other than that
column16: not much else.\n\nI think that pretty much wraps it up. For those of you who get scared easily
column17: this game is not for you. It's very different than all the other games
column21:
but I would say it's very solid.

10/10 would check the door again.

reviewText: The Final Chapter of Freddy's is here and it's the best in the series! You play as a child who has been having nightmares of the original animatronics (and a few surprise ones!) and you must defend yourself by checking everywhere in your room and close the doors when you hear breathing outside but if you flash your light to soon or to late you will get the scare of your life!\n\nIn my opinion, this is the best in the series because it refines the mechanics from the first game and adds a bit from the others to make what is possibly the most tense FNaF game ever! Whenever i go to a door i get anxious because i know i need to wait for breathing before using the light or closing the door but just waiting there scares the crap out of me and even more so the jumpscare...

reviewText:
UPDATE: Since the changes to the audio levels of this game, it has become a hell of a lot more enjoyable to play. This is easily in the top 2 of my favourite FNAF games. Still to be completed, but night 5 isn't a walk in the park right now!

The only thing I'm not enjoying about this game so far is that there's two extremes to the volumes: On the one hand you're raising your awareness for this supposed 'breathing' noise I can't seem to make out, and on the other, said risen awareness plus extremely loud jumpscare equals  a really bad headache.

As the game stands right now, it's pretty awesome, I'm impressed with this one, and is well on the way to being the best in the series - the graphics are awesome, the concept is awesome, everything about the look and feel of the game so far is awesome, but the flashlight sticks sometimes which sucks, and I'm not willing to risk my hearing just so I can deficate myself. If the other aspects of the game are good enough, you don't need loud noises to scare people - If you want that, I suggest any horror story mod on Garry's Mod.

reviewText:
The tensest moment in Five Nights at Freddy s 4 is a one-second lean. I m leaning out of a child s bedroom, a sharp departure from the Formica wasteland of Freddy Fazbear s pizzeria, peering down a hallway swallowed in darkness. I may as well be staring into a lion s mouth. When I risk a glance out one of the two flanking doors into the dark corridors beyond, my perspective skews unnervingly. I can imagine my hands hugging the wall, an ostensible anchor against the nightmares bumping in the blackness.

Nothing jumps out at me this time. The moment passes, and it's back to the same movements and mouse-clicks I ve repeated dozens of times before. I should ve yawned five minutes ago, but soon I m once more forcing my heart back down my throat for my next peek outside. This repeats for quite some minutes. If FNAF 4 needed a box blurb, it d read something like a rollercoaster of apprehension.

FNAF 4 s composition is another rivet in the series steel-clad design which immortalized its Let s Play legacy in a few short months: five 8-minute nights of staying put in a room while fending off a quick death (and a nasty jumpscare) from creepy, walking animatronic animals using careful surveillance and snappily blocking access to whatever shuffles close. Loud screeches and terrifying robotic visages are common, so a strong resolve helps. Mostly.

Boy meets demon
Above anything, developer Scott Cawthon s tenacity at constantly tweaking his formula for horror is almost Kubrickian in its meticulousness. FNAF 4 s fundamentals stay firmly acquainted—a familiarly symmetrical room; the reprise of Bonnie, Chica, Freddy, and Foxy as primary antagonists; the usage of doors as a primary defensive mechanic—but its differences offer a refreshing new presentation of the risk-reward seesaw of its predecessors.

Replacing the ever-troubled pizzeria from previous games is the nighttime bedroom of a kid who both substitutes for the hilariously underpaid security guard as the main character and clearly establishes his traumatic phobia of Freddy s friends with a constant Binding-of-Isaac-esque flow of tears. In a flagrant flouting of the status quo, the camera system is removed entirely. Checking for an impending attack involves running up to a door, leaning out, and clicking on a flashlight (thankfully with unlimited battery power) or slamming the door shut at the precise moment I anticipate something lunging for me.

As before, staying alive demands familiarization with each animatronic s behavior. Where sight and constant camera tracking facilitated this in earlier games, FNAF 4 tosses that away for a different angle: sound. Audio cues—muffled footsteps, the metallic tinkling of shifting kitchen pans, a huff of breath from something Right Beside You—indicate when to use the flashlight or seal a doorway. Being proactive is essential; a single mistake invariably delivers a booming fright. I liked that avoidance of randomness in failure, as my actions and choices solely contributed to whether or not I d soon jump out of my chair.

And that s really what Cawthon is best at: ensuring crystallized snapshots of stomach-dropping terror. FNAF 4 uses the sensitivity of your senses to prod out a panicked yelp every time. Does it work? Absolutely. It s absurdly rudimentary: straining to hear something barely above a whisper connects into a skull-shaking blast of sound and a horrible monster face stretched across the monitor. Of course it works.

A minigame involving a plushified version of Springtrap can shave two hours off each night.
But it s a bit worrisome to see an overall pivot away from what made the series so attractive in favor of a single, static mechanical loop across all five nights. The camera system, although imperfect—as later nights grew more difficult, staring too long at the video screen likely meant death—greatly defined the series identity. In FNAF 2, checking vents and winding the music box were integral counterparts to the cameras. FNAF 3 piled on the sinister inevitability of tracking a stalking killer.

In many ways, the Five Nights games require a certain respect for their atmospheric lore, a twisted menagerie of cloudy dates, murder mysteries, and inter-relationships nearly as spaghettified as a Metal Gear Solid cutscene. Stepping into Freddy s world, like flipping open a King novel or tuning into a Carpenter classic, is an investment in putting aside disbelief and reveling in the supernatural guesswork of the genre. That s sadly tougher to pull off in Five Nights at Freddy s 4; the humdrum repetition of the same sequence over and over—door, listen, flashlight, repeat—is too much of a chore to fully pull me in. It s certainly the scariest of the four, but the subtle uneasiness and self-doubt so tellingly accomplished in its older brothers is diminished.

reviewText: While I was initially skeptical on what another FNAF game could offer, since it looked like the gameplay and story elements of the games had been exhausted from the other installments, I have been proven wrong! Five Nights at Freddy's 4 effectively delivers a decent finale to the series. In this game, you're basically playing as an unamed child, confined to your bedroom in your own house, and not possessing any cameras to view the animatronics on. Obviously, we can already tell this game is different from the others, who had you playing as a security guard in a pizzeria or horror attraction. The animatronics themselves look terrifying, with sharp teeth and claws. Plus, the minigames that occur after each night seem to explain the events of the Bite of 87, a crucial plot point in the game's vague lore and backstory. I won't spoil anything, but it is pretty interesting, and even sad. The gameplay basically works liike this:  There are two doors on either side of you, like the first game, which you can check. Before shining your flashlight down the left or right hall, you must listen for the sound of heavy breathing, which means an animatronic is right next to your door, in which case you must close it and wait for the sound of footsteps to signal them leaving. If your hear breathing and shine your light, the animatronic will kill you. The use of audio cues helps to advance the creepy, intimidating atmosphere of the game, which works well. However, the breathing is very faint, so I advise you turn up your volume to hear it. There's also a closet in front of you, which will not need to be checked for most of the night. That is until Foxy runs in while you're not looking and the door noticeably creaks shut a bit. From there, you must check on Foxy and shut the door on him, until you see a Foxy plushie on the floor when you open it again. If you see Foxy as an animatronic, do the same as you did before. And finally, you can look behind you to shine your light on a bed to scare off little Mini-Freddies that will often appear on the bed. Overall, while the breathing audio could be tweaked for a better gameplay experience, and the jumpscares do get old, Five Nights at Freddys 4 serves as a satisfying conclusion to a great franchise of mystery, terror, and tension.

reviewText:
Five Nights At Freddy’s 1, 2, 3, were pretty scary, but they are NOTHING compared to Five Nights At Freddy’s 4. This game is the superior overlord of scary, after all, Scott wanted this final chapter to be the most scariest game out of all the series. One thing’s for sure, normally you play as a security guard, but FNAF 4 takes it to a whole new level when you play as a kid having nightmares—now, there IS going to be an update, but! Scott won’t open the box, and I believe that’s because almost everybody figured out all the mysteries, so Scott had nothing left to hide and decided to ditch the box, because from what I’ve heard, the box was supposed to be the key to all the mysteries and secrets, but apparently we already spoiled the secret.
Now, some people think that Fredbear was the cause of the Bite Of ’87, but this takes place at Fredbear’s family diner in 1983, so says the Fredbear & Friends Easter Egg. We know that the Bite Of 87 was at Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza, the victim was Jeremy Friztwhatever, and it took place on a birthday at 1987. Though Foxy and Mangle are the most popular suspects, they were not active or on the stage during that day, like the other old animatronics, so it HAD to be one of the toy animatronics on the stage. Toy Bonnie’s mouth isn’t wide enough, nor is Toy Freddy’s, but what about Toy Chica? Although, her beak is off at night, at day, a beak like that with sharp teeth or not, it can bite of a frontal lobe no problem. You wouldn’t believe that I’ve said this, but Toy Chica was the cause of the Bite Of ’87! But wait! What if there was a twist? You know how there’s a small fan in every game? So…what if the fan was behind it all?! YEAH, probably not!
And now, time for the case of the crying child! Most people think of him as the puppet, or is he Golden Freddy? Well, in one of the minigames, you see some brown hair sticking out of one of the suits—YES! The very first victim of the Purple Man is Golden Freddy HIMSELF! So does that STILL mean the crying child is the puppet? You could say.
Anyway, I had lots of fun playing this game, there were some serious scares—BUY IT. IT’S AMAZING.

reviewText: Now i was very supsrised that this game came so soon! But, theres alot of things i have a problem with. THERE ARE NO CAMERAS! It cant be a freddys came without cameras, you cant explore around the map! Another thing is, there is no phone guy/phone call. The thing i will give Scott is the fear, its very scary! I also thought plushtrap was in the game not a minigame -_-. The bite of 87' was also a dissapointment all it is is just a kids brother killing his brother no ghost or anything involved. It was an accident also. The main game is, is basically  just looking into 2 identcial hallways all game. I still think its a good game and i would recommend it. Its the scariest! But im sure it will get old eventually. For a phone call scott could of just done a phone call of his mom or something like that. Cameras speak for itself. Theres no office either but i can get over that. Good news is atleast we got the squeaky freddy nose right!? It is cool that you can look behind you. Theres no balloon boy and puppet either. All in all even though it may not sound like it you should still buy this game its still scary and fun! Not that much eastereggs either and not alot going on. Who is nightmare? I like how someone is under your closet and under you bed. and when they pick you up! and once you turn on the light you might be dead. Also, the title screen is dumb as well. reviewText: five nights at freddys 3 was decent, but really the story is all i really took from it. But this, this is a whole new level. Amazing story that sticks with you, great animations, chilling atmosphere, and of course, the jumpscares. These jumpscares give little to no warning and can really surprise you. This game is very good at scaring with more than just jumpscares. but anticipation. Every time you turn on the flashlight you cringe. Everytime you look behind you and then turn around again, you want to momentarily turn down the volume. And just when you think you have a handle on the system, Scott throws a curveball to make you change how you play. Great game! Good job Scott and God bless!

reviewText: Well, it's scary, for sure and being a horror game, I think that is all you really want! Unlike in the other games, you can't really anticipate when the jumpscare is coming, so they stay fresh and get you every time! Althoug sometimes the jumpscare has to load and the screen goes black for a while, in which case you know EXACTLY what is about to happen... Whcih brings me onto my first complaint - loading times. Each night takes from 30 seconds to a full 5 minutes to load, aswell as in game animations, which take about 10 seconds to load at the start of a night. It may not seem like much, but whith the speed of the animatronics you need every second to put towards keeping them away... Whcih brings me onto my second issue: the game gets too hard too quickly. Night 1 and 2 were quite good, but then at night three you are thrown into a literal torrent of jumpscares. I am a very casual gamer and, as such, struggle trying to get past 1am in night 3! I think a difficulty setting should be incorporated (e.g. an easy, medium and hard) so people like me can finish the game. Finally, for some reason, the game won't fill my full screen, even when I press F11. This is only a minor issue. However, despite this, I will continue to try my best to complete it, even if I can't get past night 3, for the brilliant, smooth gameplay that is new to FNaF. I look forward to the DLC and can't wait to find out everything about the backstory! Overall, a very good game that meets up and exceeds standards that you may want to play if your computer is beefier than mine (which isn't too great...) and you can take the jumpscares! Edit: Well, Scott has fixed the full screen isuue! Now i just have to click 'continue' to see if it loads faster! Oh dear.... Ehem, no that that is a problem, having to play it or anything.... DEFINITELY not because it is so scary or anything, he he, erm..

reviewText:
Where do I start,
I'm a total wimp when it comes to horror games, but i've been leaning towards some good ones on the xbox. One day I was watching youtube when I get a text from a friend saying FIVE NIGHTS AT FREDDY'S 4 IS SOOOO SCARY YOU MUST PLAY IT!" And I thought to myself that there's no way that this is as scary as silent hill right. I am the biggest idiot on the internet.

I honestly thought that Scott was going to screw it up with FNAF 4 after not doing such an amazing job on FNAF 3
date: but by far this is the scariest game i've played in a long time. The animatronics are beyond terrifying and I like how Scott has added all this extra detail on freedy and all them that makes them truely scary. I have barely played the game and only on night 2 because i'm that freaked out

column16: The game does it's job too well. I get so scared in the atomsphere and the feel of the dark bedroom that if I hear even the slightest noise I immediately shut the game down because i'm actually afraid. Maybe I should stop playing the game at night with the lights off and my headphones on.\n\nStill
column17:
absolutely fantastic game. You've created a masterpiece and a legacy Scott and for that you deserve all the praise the series gets. I would put this up top with some of my favourite games. This game is like a shining diamond in what I call `the bleak industry of expensive games that don't live up' I'm looking at you COD Ghosts. I also find it really odd that most indie game developers can make better games than what a million dollar games company can't do with their endless pockets of gold encrusted rubies.

Absolute must play for any fan of horror games.
OVER 9000/10"

reviewText:
UPDATE: Since the changes to the audio levels of this game, it has become a hell of a lot more enjoyable to play. This is easily in the top 2 of my favourite FNAF games. Still to be completed, but night 5 isn't a walk in the park right now!

The only thing I'm not enjoying about this game so far is that there's two extremes to the volumes: On the one hand you're raising your awareness for this supposed 'breathing' noise I can't seem to make out, and on the other, said risen awareness plus extremely loud jumpscare equals  a really bad headache.

As the game stands right now, it's pretty awesome, I'm impressed with this one, and is well on the way to being the best in the series - the graphics are awesome, the concept is awesome, everything about the look and feel of the game so far is awesome, but the flashlight sticks sometimes which sucks, and I'm not willing to risk my hearing just so I can deficate myself. If the other aspects of the game are good enough, you don't need loud noises to scare people - If you want that, I suggest any horror story mod on Garry's Mod.

reviewText:
This game. I can't even begin to describe how good this is.

First off, for my piece of crap computer, the game ran GOOD. That doesn't normally happen.

Anyway, let's get to the cons.
- For me, the game starts to pause when you load a new door.
- The tips seem to be in the way, even though you can disable them.

Pros!
+Runs very smooth.
+Nice transitions to each different area.
+A new and very scary apporach to the original point and click game.
+Scared the balls out of me unlike any of the other games (Sorry, it was just too predictable).
+Nice atmosphere. Again, scared the balls out of me.

For now, that is about all I can say! I rate the game 9.9/10, only because of the very, VERY minor issues that I experienced personally.

Thank you for another GREAT experience.

~takeo9

reviewText:
Scott has really out done himself with this monstrosity of a game.
This is by far the spookiest in the series.
I'd go as far as compare the use of sound in this game to the level of Outlast, it's honestly at that level of well executed, scary and mind messing mechanics.
It has such a chilling atmosphere.
Trailers and video gameplays don't give the spook factor justice and I would highly recommend getting it yourself.

reviewText:
This game is actually super spooky to me. Which is good. I give this game a 5 star rating :)

Night 1: Game a bit glitchy, as I try to get the light and everything to work right.. 4 am, flashlight mechanic glitches.. Bonnie jumpscares me and I nearly had a heart attack.

Fun With PlushTrap: Beat on my first try :)

Night 2: Did good, kept everyone at bay. Everything going smooth. Sees foxy's face in the closet door, nearly ran over husband's foot with chair. 5 AM: Jumpscared by that stupid cupcake!

Hasn't played any more after that.

I give you props Scott. You have finally managed to spook me... GOOD. Lol. This game is truly terrifying. Good job!
